structured_data.name: OpenStreetMap Data Export Tool
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface query, downloadable files (various formats)
structured_data.description: The Export Tool is an open service that creates customized extracts of up-to-date OpenStreetMap data. Users can download and use the data by crediting OpenStreetMap contributors. It is provided by HOT (Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team) and its partners.

structured_data.name: OpenStreetMap Network Dataset
structured_data.granularity: Global, with varying coverage detail depending on area
structured_data.description: OpenStreetMap (OSM) provides a detailed and community-updated road network dataset. It includes transportation features like highways, roads, paths, alleys, motorways, bus stops, traffic lights, and stop signs. The coverage varies by area, with some gaps where community focus has been less. TIGER data from the US Census Bureau formed the basis of the OSM road network in 2008.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: Varies, highly detailed in some areas, less so in others

structured_data.name: WorldPop - Spatial Distribution of Population
structured_data.granularity: Global (implied by 'across the globe' and extensive country list)
structured_data.data_format: GeoTIFF (implied by CCRA framework for population grids)
structured_data.description: WorldPop provides open, academically peer-reviewed methods for mapping populations at high spatial resolution across the globe. Since 2013, they have partnered with governments, UN agencies and donors to construct more than 45,000 demographic datasets, complementing traditional population sources with dynamic, high-resolution data from satellites and cellphones for mapping human population distributions. This specific dataset focuses on the spatial distribution of population.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: High spatial resolution (implied by 'high spatial resolution across the globe' and CCRA framework suggests 100m-1km for population grids)
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Since 2013 (implied by 'Since 2013, they have partnered...'), annual snapshots (implied by CCRA framework for population grids)

structured_data.name: GHS-BUILT R2015B - GHS built-up grid, derived from Landsat, multitemporal (1975, 1990, 2000, 2014) - OBSOLETE RELEASE
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files via FTP/HTTP URL, Project Website
structured_data.description: The GHS-BUILT R2015B dataset is an obsolete release of the Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL) project, supported by the European Commission, Joint Research Center. It provides multitemporal information on built-up presence derived from Landsat image collections (GLS1975, GLS1990, GLS2000, and ad-hoc Landsat 8 collection 2013/2014). The main product is a built-up area grid, which has been used to derive additional layers per each epoch. The data are offered at high, middle, and low resolutions.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: Approx. 38m (high resolution) in Spherical Mercator (EPSG:3857), 250m and 1km in Mollweide

structured_data.name: Global Human Settlement Layer
structured_data.description: The Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL) project, supported by the European Commission, Joint Research Centre, and Directorate-General for Regional and Urban Policy, produces new global spatial information, evidence-based analytics, and knowledge describing human presence on the planet. It processes satellite image data streams, census data, and crowd-sourced geographic information to report on population and built-up infrastructures. The project supports EU regional urban policy and international frameworks like Sustainable Development Goals, Global Urban Agenda, Climate Change, and the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction. The collection consists of built-up (GHS-BUILT), population (GHS-POP) grids, and city model (GHS-SMOD).

structured_data.name: GHSL: Global built-up surface 1975-2030 (P2023A)
structured_data.description: This raster dataset depicts the distribution of built-up surfaces, expressed in square metres per 100 m grid cell. The dataset measures: a) the total built-up surface, and b) the built-up surface allocated to grid cells of predominant non-residential (NRES) use. Data are spatially-temporally interpolated or extrapolated from 1975 to 2030 in 5 year intervals. Produced by the European Commission, Joint Research Centre.

structured_data.name: WorldPop-Global-Unconstrained gridded population data
structured_data.method_of_access: All relevant data are within the paper and its Supporting Information files.
structured_data.description: This dataset evaluates the cell-level accuracy of WorldPop-Global-Unconstrained gridded population datasets, particularly in Low- and Middle-Income Countries (LMICs). The simulation analysis was conducted in Khomas, Namibia, using a synthetic 2016 population with introduced levels of outdatedness and inaccuracy. The study found large cell-level errors, especially in slum cells, driven by the averaging of population densities in large areal units before model training. It suggests incorporating finer-scale training data and new building footprint datasets to improve accuracy.
